S2.T1.caption: Table 1: Our definition of industrial FL. It represents a subtype of cross-silo FL in which the collaborators are potential competitors. *stability refers to the probability that a client participates in a round.
S2.T1.table:
property cross-device cross-silo industrial FL
num. clients high low low
num. data samples low high high
processing capabilities low high high
stability* low high high
competing clients no no yes
references: An early, successful, large-scale application of FL in practice is Google’s GBoard [4, 23]. Aiming at improving their products’ next word prediction, Google had to handle millions of clients of which each only produces few datapoints, has limited computational power and drops in and out of the FL as the user loses their internet connection or turns off their phone. Now often referred to as cross-device FL, this setting can be distinguished from the comparatively newer cross-silo FL. In cross-silo FL the clients are few, but possess abundant data, high computational ability and are unlikely to drop out of the FL. Cross-silo FL often comes in the form of two hospitals deciding to collaborate without exposing their respective patients’ data to each other. While collaborating hospitals provide a very intuitive example for cross-silo FL, it lacks one crucial feature of the precise setting we focus on in this work. In what we will refer to as industrial FL, the clients are not only powerful institutions, but they are also potentially competitors. Table 1 provides an overview of these variants. Consider a company S𝑆S whose business model it is to sell AI-powered predictive devices to their customers. The customers C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} are big manufacturers and use the devices to monitor their production. S𝑆S suggests to C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} that by entering into a privacy-preserving collaboration with other manufacturers they can significantly improve their predictive accuracy. C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} will only be convinced to enter the scheme if the highest level of privacy protection can be ensured. Even more so than the privacy of individual datapoints, the protection of global statistics and trends in their data will be of concern to C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, the leaking of which could give C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} a competitive edge, for instance by timing the manufacturing of their new product based on when C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} appears to do so.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2: The NN architectures for each dataset. The number in parentheses denotes the number of layer neurons. In the case of convolution layers the kernel size and stride are also provided.
S5.T2.table:
Fashion-/MNIST Census
conv (32, 3, 1) linear (64)
conv (64, 3, 1) linear (32)
flatten linear (16)
linear (128) linear (8)
linear (10) linear (2)
references: We use a 4- layer convolutional NN with a total of 1.2M parameters for MNIST and Fashion-MNIST. For Census we use a 5-layer fully-connected NN with 3.6K total parameters. All architectures use softmax activations in the final layer and ReLU in all others. The architectures are detailed in table 2.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3: Experiment parameter overview. Note that n𝑛n, m𝑚m and l𝑙l only apply to the FL experiments.
S5.T3.table:
parameter meaning
r𝑟r epochs/rounds
s𝑠s shift epoch/round
d𝑑d dataset size
n𝑛n number of clients
m𝑚m number of shifting clients
l𝑙l local epochs
references: Before moving to the more complex FL setting we study the proposed method in a centralized setup. The effects of a DDS are experienced more directly in an isolated model, in absence of other models’ influence. The experimental setup takes the following shape. A NN is trained on MNIST for r𝑟r epochs, during which validation and SoL are logged. At epoch s𝑠s the data, consisting of d=6.7​K𝑑6.7𝐾d=6.7K samples, is swapped with data of a shifted distribution. For our experiments we simulate a label distribution shift, by shifting the ratio of even to odd numbers in the training dataset. At epoch s𝑠s the original ratio (which is close to 50-50) shifts to 80-20. We set r=20𝑟20r=20 and s=11𝑠11s=11 in all experiments. We use the Adam optimizer with learning rate = 0.0001 and the crossentropy loss function. For an overview over the parameters refer to table 3. Figure 5 shows the results. Note that the shift metrics have varying scales. The procrustes distance adheres to the interval [0,1]01[0,1], cosine similarity to [−1,1]11[-1,1] and CMD to [0,∞]0[0,\infty].
